awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: TERRG: Thresholds in ecosystem responses to rainfall gradients
awd_abstract_narration:
The biology and chemistry of streams change in response to changes in temperature and rainfall patterns.  Changes in temperature and precipitation may lead to predictable changes in the biology and chemistry of streams, while other changes are abrupt and unpredictable. In the face of environmental change, we need to understand the environmental conditions that result in predictable and abrupt responses to both the biology and chemistry of streams. This award will support research on understanding biological controls and environmental constraints on the structure and function of streams in South Texas. The research will take advantage of a semi-arid to mesic rainfall gradient that features an abrupt shift in stream community composition and ecosystem functioning at 85 cm rainfall/yr. The research will consist of a mix of field observations, manipulative experiments, and modeling. Training of undergraduate (including minority) and graduate students and outreach via an established K-12 program will contribute to the project?s broader impacts.

This project will advance our understanding of why subtle shifts in the environment can result in the significant and abrupt reorganization of ecological communities. Spatial patterns in structure and function of ecosystems along precipitation gradients indicate that threshold effects are common and widespread. Therefore, understanding the mechanisms that drive these patterns is essential for forecasting which regions of the world will undergo rapid ecosystem shifts under future environmental change. Stream ecosystems are particularly sensitive to changes in precipitation, but multiple mechanisms can be invoked to explain observed threshold effects in streams. These mechanisms include: 1) Changes in the quantity, quality, temporal stability, and predictability of the resource base, which cascade up to higher trophic levels; and conversely, 2) Changes in the temporal stability, predictability, and average environmental conditions impacting community structure, which then cascade down to ecosystem processes. By exploring these alternate and potentially simultaneously operating mechanistic hypotheses in a set of streams along a precipitation gradient in South Texas, the research will capitalize on an ideal natural experiment along with a strong foundation of preliminary data collected by the principal investigators. The results of this study will in turn inform our understanding of how similar processes operate in stream ecosystems around the world, and the basic principles will enhance our understanding of these processes in all ecosystems. The award will support training of undergraduate, graduate, postdoctoral scholars, and early career faculty at both a Hispanic Serving Institution and a primarily undergraduate institution serving 40% minorities. Undergraduates will conduct independent research and present the results at professional meetings. K-12 outreach and adult education will be conducted through the SIU Center for Ecology and Graduate Research Assistants Supporting Science (GRASS) program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is strong evidence that the global climate is rapidly changing.  Since the pre-industrial period, the global mean temperature has increased 0.8 -1.2 oC.  Coinciding with increasing temperatures, the timing, intensity, and frequency of extreme events, like storms and droughts, has also changed significantly leading to changes in precipitation patterns. Climate models predict that some regions will become more arid while others will become more mesic. Therefore, while temperature effects have received the greatest attention considering climate change, understanding the effects of changes in precipitation is also critically important.

 

Changes in precipitation are particularly important for streams and rivers as stream flow is inherently linked to precipitation, which is a strong driver of a stream’s flow regime. The magnitude, duration, frequency, and timing of stream flow is key for stream ecosystem processes such as transporting nutrients and water quality, species adaptations, and production of stream communities. Changes to the flow regime may therefore alter stream ecosystem functioning under future climate change scenarios.

 

Quantifying how much energy is produced and consumed is vital to understand how an ecosystem operates. In streams and rivers, we use ‘ecosystem metabolism’ to measure the day-to-day changes of how much energy stream primary producers (i.e., algae) make and the consumption of energy by both autotrophs and heterotrophs (i.e., microbes and algae to fishes). We often measure this production and consumption of energy as gross primary production (GPP) and ecosystem respiration (ER), respectively.  GPP and ER are considered cornerstone processes as they encompass the energetics of the entire community living in the stream from microbes and algae to fishes. Specifically, for work led by Sam Houston State University (SHSU, Huntsville, TX, USA), to explore how changes in stream flow owing to climate change may alter GPP and ER, we used a space for time substitution to explore how GPP and ER varied across a gradient of annual precipitation in 9 coastal plain streams in Texas, USA.

 

Texas coastal plain streams had very low primary production, regardless of the amount of annual precipitation, where the average GPP ranged from 0.3 - 0.9 g O2 m2 d-1.  ER exceeded GPP, ranging from 1- 4.9 g O2 m2 d-1 throughout the year across all streams spanning the precipitation gradient. These coastal plain ecosystems likely had low primary production because these streams receive little light owing to shading by steep stream banks. In addition, across the precipitation gradient the flow regime of these streams was relatively flashy, i.e., stream flow increases and decreases quickly. Most of the substrate found in these streams were soft, fine sediments that were disturbed relatively easily resulting in low algal growth. Therefore, these streams could be classified as 'dark and stormy' regardless of the steep precipitation gradient, resulting in relatively low primary production and where these streams likely rely on terrestrial subsidies of energy at the ecosystem scale. 

 

Our understanding of stream and river GPP and ER has increased due to technological advances in sensors and computing power. Since the first ecosystem scale estimate of GPP and ER in the 1950s, we have moved from estimating 1 day of metabolism for 1 stream to estimating decades of daily fluxes of GPP and ER in hundreds of streams. However, most of this knowledge is based on temperate North American and European streams. We have little understanding of subtropical and tropical regions and how these streams may or may not operate differently in terms of energy balance of production and respiration. The data we have collected supported by this project adds thousands of data points to a relatively small data set from subtropical and tropical regions, thereby allowing us to start to better understand how these ecosystems function.

 

For SHSU, this project provided funds and support for 1 graduate student (Master of Science) who successfully completed the graduate program in May 2022. In addition, 4 other graduate (Master of Science) and 5 undergraduate students from SHSU were involved in the data collection, processing, and/or data analyses. The 5 undergraduate students were able to scaffold their experience on this NSF project to obtain funding from SHSU to expand the work we did in the coastal plain Texas streams to local streams near the University.
